Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Michael Adan Caballero of Colorado State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Determining the origin of secreted fatty acids in a biofuel cyanobacterium," during the summer of 2012 at The University of Tokyo in Tokyo, Japan. The host scientist is Dr. Naoki Sato.

The cyanobacteria Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 has been engineered to overproduce and export fatty acids, potentially revolutionizing the economics of algal biofuels. This research uses carbon-labeling to determine the source of these fatty acids, hypothesized to originate from either the fatty acid synthase or membrane lipids. It is part of the global effort of developing sustainable bioenergy.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With an ever-increasing global fuel demand, biofuels can supplement existing supply chains. Biofuels from algae have already been tested in fuel blends for commercial airliners (“Frying the Friendly Skies”) and the U.S. Navy (“Dynamic Fuels and Solazyme Partner to Supply Renewable Fuel to U.S. Navy”). As addressed in the first article, production of algal biofuel remains expensive. Additional research and development could directly address the economic bottlenecks of this technology, making ‘pond scum’ a worthwhile investment for the energy sector.

One strategy of generating fuel from algae is to enhance production of fatty acids, which are components of common fats that one can find in a kitchen, such as butter and oil. Fatty acids may be processed into a diesel replacement by a relatively simple chemical conversion. Furthermore, scientists have been able to modify algae strains to enhance the production of fatty acids. An increased production rate of fatty acids improves the economics of this technology, as more unprocessed biofuel is generated per each algae.  

A concern about this approach is that fatty acids serve fundamental purposes in the cell, most notably in composing the cell membrane. Membranes define the inside from the outside of the cell and their integrity is essential for effective photosynthesis. If algae are not effective at making their membranes because they are too busy secreting fatty acids, the cells may be functioning at an overall lower capacity. The primary objective from this research was to compare the lipid (cell membrane’s fat) composition between an algae strain that was modified to enhance fatty acid production and one that was unchanged. 

Under the guidance of Dr. Naoki Sato at the University of Tokyo, I was able to effectively tackle this question. Dr. Sato has extensively studied algae lipid composition. With his help, I was able to generate data for this comparison, as well as analyze the rate at which lipids were being generated, including both membranes and fatty acids. It appears that despite higher production rates and concentrations of fatty acids in the modified strains, their lipid profiles do not change significantly. This may mean that production of fatty acids may be pushed further, and if yield of fatty acids may be further improved without compromising cell membrane composition, then the economics of this biotechnology may further be improved.

            The funding for this project enabled me to perform research at the University of Tokyo. As one of the world’s best universities, the quality of research and instruction was unparalleled. Furthermore, the University of Tokyo has an extensive algal research community. I was able to learn about how research was performed in a different country. Cultural and social structure differences exist between the U.S. and Japan, many of which carry over into the lab. These insights are intangible assets from my summer research and helped me become a more globally minded scientist. Finally, this project allowed me to develop a network with excellent researchers in Tokyo, generating a starting point for continued international collaboration.

 

Nicas, Jack. “Frying the Friendly Skies.” Wall Street Journal 8 November 2011.

“Dynamic Fuels and Solazyme Partner to Supply Renewable Fuel to U.S. Navy.” Wall Street Journal 5 December 2011.
